data.title: SIVR: The Cheapest ETF Proxy On Physical Silver
data.description:
Introduction To The abrdn Physical Silver Shares ETF

The abrdn Physical Silver Shares ETF (SIVR), which made its debut on the markets on July 20, 2009, has so far accumulated total assets under management of over $6.6B. SIVR, which belongs to Aberdeen Group PLC (a UK-based investment manager), is issued by the latters wholly-owned subsidiary- abrdn ETFs Sponsor LLC [AESL]. To procure a stake in SIVR, investors will need to pay an expense ratio of 0.3%. SIVR does not make any dividends.

What Does SIVR Do?

SIVRs chief purpose it to serve as an accessible and cost-efficient vehicle for those who want to profit from the movement of physical silver prices (and not silver futures). SIVR, is basically the owner of 75.4m troy ounces of physical silver bullion bars, which are stored and maintained in secured vaults in the UK.

Also consider that rather than being set up as an investment company that resorts to active management strategies to generate returns, SIVR is structured as a grantor trust. This means the onus here is to just hold the physical silver and issue shares against it (which investors buy, giving them fractional ownership of the entire silver held), rather than selling the metal when it goes higher, or purchasing it when it dips, or enhancing returns through the use of derivative contracts, etc.

Who Are the Main Parties Within SIVRs Setup?

Behind SIVRs successful operations there are a number of key parties that are worth noting:

  • Sponsor: As covered in the initial section of this article, this role is carried out by AESL, whose responsibility is to create and register shares of SIVR on the NYSE Arca, and issue new shares when required. AESL can be construed to be the general manager of this set-up and is also responsible for picking other key parties (as described below) that are essential to the running of SIVR.
  • Custodian: The silver bars that SIVR holds arent held by the sponsor, but by a custodian called ICBC Standard Bank PLC [ISBP]. Interestingly ISBP only took over custodianship responsibilities of SIVR in May 2024 [before that custodianship duties were carried out by JP Morgan Chase] who parks them in their London vaults.
  • Trustee: Trusteeship is carried out by the Bank of New York Mellon Corporation (BK) that looks into the day-to-day administrative work (calculation of the daily NAV, accounting entries, creating grantor trust tax information, etc.)
  • Metal inspector: To ensure that the quality of the bullion bars held in the vaults doesnt disintegrate, the services of Bureau Veritas Commodities UK Ltd (BVRDF), is also tapped twice a year. Besides a standard inspection at the end of the year, the first inspection takes place on a random date during the year.

What Are the Risks Associated With SIVR?

Since SIVR is established as a grantor trust that holds physical metal, it exhibits some tax inefficiencies that may be seen as cumbersome to a fair few. For instance, long-term capital gains [LTCG] are taxed at a higher collectibles rate of 28% rather than 20% LTCG rate.

In addition to that, because SIVR is a grantor trust, it does not pay any income tax, with all tax liabilities flowing through to its investors. Also, we know this trust has various expenses to incur, but because theres no income coming in to cover those expenses, a fraction of the silver owned needs to be sold every month to meet those expenses (also existing holders of SIVR own less silver every month, as a pro-rate share of their holdings been cashed in every month to meet those expenses). Also, even though there is some disposition of investors assets every month, the proceeds dont come to investors accounts, yet they are charged with a capital gain or loss and dont receive a tax break for the same either. This facet could prove to be particularly troubling to those who own SIVR in taxable brokerage accounts (as opposed to IRA or 401(k)s)).

While silver does exhibit shades of a safe haven when risk sentiment in the markets dip or geopolitical risks spike, this defensive trait certainly isnt as pronounced as gold. Also, silvers prospects are closely tied to the health of global industrials, making this quite a risky bet that could face some pressure during global cyclical downswings. Investors should also consider that unlike diversified ETFs, SIVR is a single-commodity ETF, which certainly elevates its risk profile. This can be validated even further by SIVRs standard deviation and volatility readings which are roughly 3x more than a standard ETF, making this product unsuitable for investors with conservative risk appetite.

Silver has an inverse relationship with the US Dollar, so if the latter witnesses meaningful appreciation, this could be detrimental for SIVR.

Silver has benefited through multi-year deficits (including 2026, we will see will be six straight years of deficits), but investors should also note that these deficits are shrinking by the year (for instance FY25s estimated deficit of 95-149Moz, is poised to shrink to 68Moz this year) and in a few years, theres potential for the market position to normalize, which ultimately wont reflect well on prices.

If investors are thinking of pursuing SIVR with the intention of also procuring a quarterly, semi-annual or annual dividend bonus (which is standard practice with most ETFs today), then this isnt the right product. The holdings (equities, bonds, derivative contracts) in most ETFs usually generate some form of income, or are sometimes lent out, to earn additional income, which is then passed on to these shareholders by way of distributions, but in SIVRs case, it just plainly holds physical silver, and its returns are just a function of the price movements of silver (and nothing more) after accounting for trust expenses.

Investors should also note that SIVR hasnt taken out an insurance policy to cover its silver holdings; insurance support if any, only comes in the form of the insurance that the custodian-ISBP, has taken for its entire operation (and not just the silver it holds for SIVR).

Who Is SIVR For?

SIVR is meant for those who want a cost-efficient and transparent route to owning physical silver. For further context note that, SIVRs expense ratio of 0.3% is already 20bps lower than the median expense ratio of all ETFs.

Facilitating such a low expense ratio in the silver space is not easy to come by, with competing products priced at a much higher range of 0.5-0.95% (admittedly, some of these products are leveraged ETFs which will understandably cost more, but even against the unleveraged ETFs SIVR has a strong edge).

SIVR also scores high on transparency, with its custodian- ISBP, providing a bar list which is updated every day.

Investors attracted to SIVR are typically also those who are likely feeling emboldened about the long-term health and the buoyancy of the global industrial landscape; after all, roughly 60% of silver demand comes from the industrial sector.

Within industrials, those who expect the solar wave to gain traction will like this product, as modern solar cells are increasingly seeing higher silver paste per cells than older models. Also, if investors are big on growing electrification of the modern world, a position in SIVR would represent a good bet, as silver is the most conductive metal around.

SIVR would also be suitable for those who expect the debasement and devaluation of fiat currencies.

SIVR and silver would also represent a good diversifier for US equity-heavy portfolios; we say this because over the last decade, the price of silver has exhibited relatively low correlation (less than 0.25x) with the US equity benchmark- the S&P 500.

Peers Of SIVR

If not for SIVR, investors who want unleveraged ETF access to physical silver could also look at the iShares Silver Trust (SLV) or the Sprott Physical Silver Trust (PSLV).

SLV is the most established product out of the lot, with a trading history that goes back to April 2006 (whereas PSLV got listed around 15 months after SIVR in October 2010). Relative longevity certainly appears to have played a part in the respective AUMs of these products, although SLV is well ahead of the other two at nearly $50B of AUM. SLVs strong drawing power can also be felt through the liquidity it attracts every day (around $8B of dollar volumes, whereas the other two see less than half a billion dollars).

PSLV, which is the priciest out of the lot (expense ratio of 0.57%), is meant for those also want the option of redeeming their stake through physical silver (and not just cash). Both SLV and SIVR dont have this useful redemption option. It must also be said that for the degree of AUM it has accumulated, PSLV sees very strong daily liquidity (almost half its total AUM). In addition to that, PSLV is set up as a Canadian trust, and thus the IRS recognizes it as a Passive Foreign Investment Corporation (PFIC). The benefit of this is that long-term capital gains could be a lot lower at 15-20%, rather than the 28% rate that the other two alternatives are subject to.

Summary

SIVR represents the most cost-efficient route for investors who want to garner access to physical silver. However, given that SIVR is set up as a grantor trust, it remains susceptible to some tax inefficiencies, and its single metal focus also results in high volatility.

This article answers these three main questions about SIVR:

  • Who are the main players behind SIVR?
  • What type of investor is SIVR suitable for, and what are the risks associated with it?
  • What are some alternatives to SIVR?

data.title: Hertz: Making Some Progress (Rating Upgrade)
data.description:
Thursday morning, we received fourth-quarter results from Hertz (HTZ). The rental car company has been looking to turn around its business after a failed bet on electric vehicles led to significant losses. The latest results indicated that things are improving, but the company still faces a number of headwinds as we progress through 2026.

Previous Coverage of the Name

It was nearly a year ago that I last covered the company, right as the overall market was getting worried over President Trump's global tariff strategy. Hertz shares had jumped on hopes that rising used car prices would lower the company's depreciation expenses and lead to better resale values. However, things haven't worked out totally as expected, as since then, the stock has only risen about 6.7%, compared to a more than 24% surge in the S&P 500.

A Look at the Q4 Results and Recent News

For the final period of 2025, Hertz reported revenues of $2.028 billion. While this number was down $12 million over the prior year period, it did beat street estimates by about $100 million. The company reported a small increase in average rentable vehicles, but it had a slightly lower revenue per unit figure. While the International segment showed about 10% top-line growth, the much larger Americas division showed a 3% decline.

Hertz was able to narrow its losses quite a bit in the quarter, mainly due to a 21% drop in monthly depreciation per vehicle. The company also reduced its direct vehicle and operating expenses while also showing a decline in interest costs. However, the company still lost nearly $200 million, and this figure included a significant benefit from the reduction in the fair value of its public warrants. For the year, the net loss was $747 million.

In the current quarter, management expects a mid-single-digit revenue increase, well above the street's estimate for less than 2%. The company believes its commercial strategy is paying off, and it is focused on its off-airport and mobility business this year. I'll be curious to see if this progress continues later in 2026 as electric vehicle giant Tesla (TSLA) expands its robo-taxi network, which could be a headwind for the overall rental car industry.

The other major piece of news recently was a big loss for the company. The U.S. Supreme Court declined to hear a case regarding the company's bond payouts related to its Chapter 11 bankruptcy. As a result of this, the lower court's ruling stayed in place, so the company made a $346 million payment in January as detailed in its 10-K filing. The Delaware Bankruptcy Court will determine whether any additional amounts are due.

Balance Sheet and Cash Flow Update

Hertz finished 2025 with $565 million in cash on the balance sheet. However, due to the capital-intensive nature of the business, it also had over $17 billion in total debt. At nearly $16.5 billion, the net debt total worsened by almost three quarters of a billion dollars last year and is up more than $3.56 billion in the last three years alone.

The problem for Hertz right now is that it's not generating enough cash to cover the net costs of its capital expenditures. In 2025, total operating cash flow was $1.625 billion, down about $600 million from the year before. However, the company's net vehicle expenditures after disposals were about $2.1 billion, so true free cash flow was deeply negative. If things continue as is, Hertz will need to raise further capital through either debt or equity.

The Current Valuation Picture

With Hertz losing money currently, there is no price-to-earnings ratio to calculate here. On a price-to-sales basis, Hertz goes for about 0.18 times its currently expected revenues for this year. That's less than half the roughly 0.39 times that competitor Avis Budget Group (CAR) goes for. Hertz is projected to show more revenue growth in 2026, but Avis didn't lose as much money last year (after impairment charges).

On the analyst side of things, it's a mixed picture. Of the 9 analysts who have covered the stock in the past three months, there were six hold ratings and three sells. The current average price target is $4.75, implying more than 7% upside from current levels. That average has risen from $3.39 a year ago, but three years ago it was nearly $25.

Final Thoughts and Recommendation

As Hertz continues its turnaround efforts, Q4 revenues came in better than street estimates on Thursday. The quarter's decline wasn't nearly as bad as expected, and things are looking even better in the current period. The only problem here is that the business is very capital intensive, and the company isn't generating enough operating cash flow to cover its vehicle purchases, leading to a large and growing net debt pile.

Given the valuation seems very depressed now compared to a key industry peer, I'm upgrading the stock today from "Sell" to "Neutral." While I don't like the overall financial situation here, some progress has been made recently, and management did paint a pretty rosy picture for the start of this year. I'm not ready yet to fully buy in, given an ever-changing mobility industry, so I'd like to see another quarter or two of major progress here.
